title-group.article-title: The Shifting Sands of Nutrient Provision in the ICU

body.p: Consensus among clinical guidelines indicate that early initiation of enteral nutrition (EN) is the preferred method of nutrient administration in critically ill patients with adequate gastrointestinal function.1-3 However, in these critically ill patients, much debate surrounds how much, the optimal route, and when to administer nutrients.4-6

Dr Pichard and colleagues report new results of a randomized controlled trial wherein they tested the hypothesis that individually optimized energy provision by supplemental parenteral nutrition (SPN) for 6 days after day 3 of intensive care unit (ICU) admission could improve clinical outcome in severely ill patients for whom EN alone is insufficient.7 Patients were enrolled on day 3 of ICU stay if they were expected to stay greater than 5 days and survive greater than 7 days, and if EN provided was less than 60% of targeted energy needs. SPN allowed for provision of energy (SPN 103%; EN 77%) and protein targets (SPN 100%; EN 71%), wherein energy administered between day 4 and day 8 was 28 kcal/kg per day in the SPN group, versus 20 kcal/kg per day in the EN group (p < 0.0001). During the intervention period, mean cumulative energy balance was 124 kcal in the SPN group and −2317 kcal in the EN group (p < 0.0001). Nosocomial infections between day 9 and 28—the primary outcome—was reduced in the SPN group (SPN 27%; EN 38%) with a hazard ratio of 0.65 (95% CI 0.43-0.97; p = 0.0338). Secondary outcomes such as antibiotic use for nosocomial infections (−0.4, 95% CI −0.8 to −0.0; p = 0.0337) and hours on mechanical ventilation in patients without nosocomial infection (−1.3, 95% CI −2.1 to −0.4; P = 0.0028) were reduced with SPN.

The advantages of SPN reported by Dr Pichard and colleagues7 contrast those of The Tight Calorie Control Study (TICACOS)8 and the Impact of Early Parenteral Nutrition Completing Enteral Nutrition in Adult Critically Ill Patients (EPaNIC)9 trial. Despite differences in study design, patient demographics, and the timing of intervention and outcome assessment, a key difference in the results obtained among these studies may relate to the administration of optimal nutrient requirements. The value of vigilant indirect calorimetry assessment was demonstrated by Singer and colleagues with TICACOS.8 However, in both the TICACOS and EPaNIC trial, concerns remain regarding overfeeding in the intervention groups due to repeated inclusion of nonnutritional energy delivery and/or high glucose load, respectively. These differences reinforce the need to feed precisely with watchful care for both under- and overcumulative nutrient balance. Importantly, results from this Swiss trial demonstrate that complementary enteral and parenteral therapies can reduce nosocomial infection in critically ill patients. However, these investigators also remind us that careful metabolic monitoring, consideration for nonnutritional energy sources, and vigilant titration of energy delivery are important elements in our quest to improve clinical outcomes.
As we look toward the future, let’s ensure the data lead the way.
